title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: BoneCellType package aims help assign cell types single-cell RNA-seq clusters derived bone samples. BoneCellType uses custom-assembled database bone-relevant markers (assembly approach described ). two approaches introduced reach goal: 1) marker overrepresentation analysis using Fisher’s exact test, 2) gene (marker) set enrichment analysis. Note! results produced BoneCellType assign definitive cell-type labels; initial prediction based statistical testing manual curation needed.

title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: Let’s load BoneCellType package along packages whose functions used tutorial. input functions presented data.frame variable markers (.e. features) individual clusters can obtained using Seurat FindMarkers function. provide previously generated example dataset.
code: library(BoneCellType) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  # example dataset varMarkerFile = system.file("extdata", "cluster_variable_features.csv",                              package = "BoneCellType") varMarkers = read.csv(varMarkerFile, sep = ",")  # show top rows of the example dataset head(varMarkers) #>           p_val avg_log2FC pct.1 pct.2     p_val_adj cluster   gene #> 1 1.551369e-202   7.978416 0.664 0.021 2.861810e-198       0  Hemgn #> 2 5.127751e-104  16.393282 0.935 0.169 9.459163e-100       0  Mki67 #> 3  4.012367e-98   5.801448 0.701 0.078  7.401614e-94       0 Diaph3 #> 4  4.156995e-96  11.168982 0.776 0.107  7.668409e-92       0   Ank1 #> 5  1.869814e-87   8.421892 0.776 0.120  3.449246e-83       0   Sptb #> 6  1.936041e-87   7.841105 0.785 0.123  3.571415e-83       0  Top2a

title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: calculate marker overrepresentation use markerEnrich function. automatically provides database bone-relevant markers. Results can dirrectly plotted associated plotMarkerEnrich function, output editable ggplot object. Note: default setting markerEnrich use available variable markers per cluster, based practical experience, reliable results can achieved selecting top markers setting parameter topN (shown example ). Default mode selects top markers based log2FC, can changed setting parameter sortBy=“padj”. Changing sortBy, however, usually change much.  labels x-axis contain following information <cluster number __ cell type __ source database>. Dashed line indicates padj = 0.05. Let’s now look format markerEnrich results. shown, output table following variables- cluster: cluster number / cellType: cell type / database: source database markers originate / p: p-value / oddsRatio: odds ratio / n_olaps: number overlap variable markers (features) marker database / overlaps: list individual overlapping markers / padj: adjusted p-value /neg_log10_padj: -log10(padj). Recommendation: Try different settings markerEnrich function try different topN, sortBy arguments. general wouldn’t set byDatabase FALSE, TISSUES database relatively lot markers (sure ) can skew results. overall definitely recommend explore whole result table, see markers drive associated results cell type assignment makes sense.
code: # run overrepresentation analysis uasing top 10 variable markers (features) per cluster ORres = markerEnrich(varMarkers, topN = 10)  # plot the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerEnrich(ORres, topN = 5) # show top 2 significant result for each cluster topORres = ORres %>%    group_by(cluster) %>%    top_n(n = 2, wt = neg_log10_padj)  topORres #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #> # Groups:   cluster [3] #>   cluster cellType           database       p oddsRatio n_olaps overlaps    padj #>     <int> <chr>              <chr>      <dbl>     <dbl>   <int> <chr>      <dbl> #> 1       0 Macrophage         CellMar… 1.05e-4     169.        2 Mki67,T… 2.20e-3 #> 2       0 Erythroblast       MSigDB   7.99e-5      48.4       3 Top2a,C… 2.20e-3 #> 3       1 Fibroblast         CellMar… 1.32e-5     515.        2 Col1a2,… 8.31e-4 #> 4       1 Preosteoblast      CellMar… 9.43e-4    2339.        1 Col1a1   9.90e-3 #> 5       2 Central memory T … CellMar… 2.36e-3     574.        1 Lef1     1.24e-2 #> 6       2 Central memory T … CellMar… 2.36e-3     574.        1 Lef1     1.24e-2 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: neg_log10_padj <dbl>

title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: perfeorm GSEA analysis (use fgsea package) use markerGSEA function. Similarly markerEnricha, function also automatically provides database bone-relevant markers. Results can plotted plotMarkerGSEA function, output editable ggplot object. Unlike overrepresentationa analysis, GSEA analysis (markerGSEA ) uses full list markers associated given cluster sorted log2(fold change) values. Note list variable markers (features) per cluster usually long, therefore overrepresentation analysis (introduced ) might suitable.  labels x-axis contain following information <cluster number __ source database __ cell type>. Dashed line indicates padj = 0.05. Let’s now look format markerGSEA results. shown, output table following variables- pathaway: defines set markers used GSEA analysis / pval: p-value / padj: adjusted p-value / log2err: expected error standard deviation p-value logarithm / ES: enrichment score / NES: normalized enrichment score /size: size pathway removing genes present ‘names(stats)’ / leadingEdge: vector indexes leading edge genes drive enrichment /cluster: cluster number. Note: can see plot , results cluster 2 low significance terms adjusted p-value. case might useful plot NES values instead. Let’s look .
code: # run GSEA GSEAres = markerGSEA(varMarkers)  # plot the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerGSEA(GSEAres, topN = 5) # show top 2 significant result for each cluster topGSEAres = GSEAres %>%    group_by(cluster) %>%    top_n(n = 2, wt = -padj)  topGSEAres #> # A tibble: 34 × 9 #> # Groups:   cluster [3] #>    pathway             pval  padj log2err     ES   NES  size leadingEdge cluster #>    <chr>              <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <int> <chr>         <int> #>  1 CellMarker2_mous… 0.0861 0.376   0.178 -0.905 -1.45     7 Hba-a1            0 #>  2 CellMarker2_mous… 0.172  0.376   0.123 -0.852 -1.36     6 S100a9,Ltf…       0 #>  3 CellMarker2_mous… 0.0912 0.376   0.170 -0.901 -1.44     8 Hba-a1,Hbb…       0 #>  4 CellMarker2_mous… 0.0836 0.376   0.188 -0.927 -1.45     5 Hba-a1            0 #>  5 MSigDB__Granuloc… 0.113  0.376   0.160 -0.896 -1.40     5 S100a9,Mal…       0 #>  6 MSigDB__Granuloc… 0.139  0.376   0.126 -0.829 -1.36    13 S100a9,Mal…       0 #>  7 MSigDB__Hematopo… 0.101  0.376   0.161 -0.889 -1.42     8 S100a9,Mal…       0 #>  8 MSigDB__Late_pro… 0.176  0.376   0.121 -0.847 -1.35     6 S100a9,S10…       0 #>  9 MSigDB__Macropha… 0.153  0.376   0.128 -0.847 -1.35     8 S100a9,Ltf…       0 #> 10 MSigDB__Mature_a… 0.182  0.376   0.119 -0.843 -1.35     6 Malat1            0 #> # ℹ 24 more rows # plot the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerGSEA(GSEAres, topN = 5, plotNES = TRUE)

title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: functions presented provide multiple options run analyses plot results. Additionally, users can provide sets cell type / tissue markers (bone-related). Furthermore, outputs plotting function editable ggplot objects. section cover options customize provided functions.

what: a. Provide custom set of markers
title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: part pf package provide set bone-related markers. inputs overrepresentation analysis vs. GSEA analysis slightly different format (data.frame vs. list, respectively). let’s look format inputs provide functions package.

previous_headings: Custom settings > a. Provide custom set of markers
title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: marker database provided package overrepresentation analysis can accessed following way: want provide set markers, data.frame must following columns: tissue, cellType, gene, database. row must contain one gene (.e. marker). Let’s now look use markerDatabase object overrepresentation analysis markerEnrich.  Using input way allows us example filter markers coming sources might trust much. Let’s say like omit markers coming CellMarker2_mouse_sc database (source). Let’s look .  can see, cell types CellMarker2_mouse_sc reported results, since markers filtered .
code: # access set of markers markerDatabase = markerDatabase  # view variables in the markerDatabase data.frame head(markerDatabase) #>   tissue              cellType       gene          database #> 1   Bone            Osteoclast       Acp5 CellMarker2_mouse #> 2   Bone       Osteogenic cell Galectin-3 CellMarker2_mouse #> 3   Bone            Osteoclast       Ctsk CellMarker2_mouse #> 4   Bone            Osteoclast        Ctr CellMarker2_mouse #> 5   Bone            Osteoclast       Mmp9 CellMarker2_mouse #> 6   Bone Mesenchymal stem cell       Cd45 CellMarker2_mouse # run overrepresentation analysis uasing top 10 variable markers (features) per cluster ORres2 = markerEnrich(varMarkers = varMarkers, markerDB = markerDatabase, topN = 10)  # plot the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerEnrich(ORres2, topN = 5) # filter out markers originating from CellMarker2_mouse source filtDB = markerDatabase %>%    dplyr::filter(database != "CellMarker2_mouse_sc")    # pass the filtered set of markers to overrepresentation analysis ORresFilt = markerEnrich(varMarkers = varMarkers, markerDB = filtDB, topN = 10)  # plot the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerEnrich(ORresFilt, topN = 5)

previous_headings: Custom settings > a. Provide custom set of markers
title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: Marker input GSEA analysis form named list. names correspond given set content given set string vector containing given markers. 4 marker sets included package, let’s look . List cell type specific markers merged multiple source databases List tissue specific markers merged multiple source databases List cell type specific markers separated source database List cell type specific markers merged multiple source databases Now let’s pass selected set markers markerGSEA function. Note: provide list markers markers variable, systemLevel byDatabase options anything anymore. create list according needs.
code: # access set of cell type markers (merged from multiple source databases) cellType_list = cellType_list  # view contents (maximum 6 markers per sublist) headList(cellType_list) #> $Adipocyte #> [1] "Apoe"   "Lpl"    "Adipoq" "Cebpb"  "Pparg"  "Cebpa"  #>  #> $`Adult stem cell` #> [1] "Cd34" "Ly6a" "Thy1" #>  #> $`Alternatively activated macrophage` #> [1] "Arg1"   "Retnla" #>  #> $`Anti-inflammatory macrophage` #> [1] "Cx3cr1" #>  #> $`Antibody-secreting cell` #> [1] "Cd81"  "Il6st" "Cd39"  "Epcam" #>  #> $`Antigen-presenting cell` #> [1] "Cd83"   "Ccr7"   "H2-Ab1" "Ptprc"  "H2-Eb1" "Mhc Ii" # access set of tissue markers (merged from multiple source databases) tissue_list = tissue_list  # view contents (maximum 6 markers per sublist) headList(tissue_list) #> $Bone #> [1] "Acp5"       "Galectin-3" "Ctsk"       "Ctr"        "Mmp9"       #> [6] "Cd45"       #>  #> $`Bone marrow` #> [1] "Flt3"   "Cr2"    "Csf1r"  "Adgre1" "Fcer1g" "Fcgr1"  #>  #> $`Bone or Chondrocyte` #> [1] "Twist2"        "Tnfaip6"       "Gm13652"       "Alx4"          #> [5] "a"             "2700069I18Rik" #>  #> $Chondrocyte #> [1] "Pi15"   "Kcnt2"  "Fmo1"   "Rgs5"   "Atp1a2" "Lamc3" # access set of cell type markers separated by source cellTypeSource_list = cellTypeSource_list  # view contents (maximum 6 markers per sublist) headList(cellTypeSource_list) #> $CellMarker2_mouse__Adipocyte #> [1] "Apoe"   "Lpl"    "Adipoq" "Cebpb"  "Pparg"  "Cebpa"  #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Adult stem cell` #> [1] "Cd34" "Ly6a" "Thy1" #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Alternatively activated macrophage` #> [1] "Arg1"   "Retnla" #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Anti-inflammatory macrophage` #> [1] "Cx3cr1" #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Antibody-secreting cell` #> [1] "Cd81"  "Il6st" "Cd39"  "Epcam" #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Antigen-presenting cell` #> [1] "Cd83"   "Ccr7"   "H2-Ab1" "Ptprc"  "H2-Eb1" "Mhc Ii" # access set of tissue markers separated by source tissueSource_list = tissueSource_list  # view contents (maximum 6 markers per sublist) headList(tissueSource_list) #> $CellMarker2_mouse__Bone #> [1] "Acp5"       "Galectin-3" "Ctsk"       "Ctr"        "Mmp9"       #> [6] "Cd45"       #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse__Bone marrow` #> [1] "Flt3"   "Cr2"    "Csf1r"  "Adgre1" "Fcer1g" "Fcgr1"  #>  #> $CellMarker2_mouse_sc__Bone #> [1] "Thy1"    "Fap"     "Pdpn"    "Col22a1" "Lgr5"    "Ngp"     #>  #> $`CellMarker2_mouse_sc__Bone marrow` #> [1] "Pdcd1"  "Sell"   "Ly6a"   "Ifng"   "Arg1"   "Cxcl10" #>  #> $MSigDB__Bone #> [1] "Slc9a2"   "Camk1d"   "Tnks1bp1" "S100a11"  "Tmub1"    "Spon2"    #>  #> $`MSigDB__Bone marrow` #> [1] "Ptma"   "Oaz1"   "Xpot"   "Itk"    "Ubb"    "Ubb-ps" # run GSEA with your set of markers GSEAcellTypeSource = markerGSEA(varMarkers = varMarkers, markers = cellTypeSource_list)  # plot NES of the top 5 most significant results plotMarkerGSEA(GSEAcellTypeSource, topN = 5, plotNES = TRUE)

title: BoneCellType: R package for bone-relevant cell type assignment
text: outputs plotting functions editable ggplot objects can adjust liking. Let’s look . First let’s generate default plot.  Let’s now change color scheme add plot title.
code: # run overrepresentation analysis uasing top 10 variable markers (features) per cluster ORres = markerEnrich(varMarkers, topN = 10)  # plot the top 5 most significant results p = plotMarkerEnrich(ORres, topN = 5) p library(viridisLite) p = p +    scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "D", direction = -1) +   ggtitle("Bone cell type overrepresentation analysis") p

title:
The function markerEnrich calculates enrichment of cluster-specific
variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone tissue-specific marker
database. — markerEnrich
code: markerEnrich(   varMarkers,   markerDB = NULL,   systemLevel = "cellType",   byDatabase = TRUE,   topN = Inf,   sortBy = "log2FC" )

title:
The function markerEnrich calculates enrichment of cluster-specific
variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone tissue-specific marker
database. — markerEnrich
text: varMarkers data.frame containing variable markers cluster reported FindAllMarkers function Seurat package. markerDB Optional data.frame containing cell type-specific markers. data.frame contain following columns: tissue (specifies tissue), cellType (specifies cell type), gene (contains markers), database (specifies source markers obtained) systemLevel Optional string specifying systematic level perform enrichment, options: "cellType" "tissue". Default: "cellType". byDatabase Optional logical variable specifying enrichment performed separately database (.e. source  markers obtained): option TRUE (default). database column markerDB ignored enrichment done available markers given cellType tissue: option FALSE. topN Optional integer specifying many top variable markers per cluster used enrichment analysis. Default: variable markers used. sortBy Optional string used topN option used. Specifies log2(fold change): option "log2FC" (default) adjusted p-value: option "padj" used select topN variable markers.

title:
The function markerEnrich calculates enrichment of cluster-specific
variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone tissue-specific marker
database. — markerEnrich
text: data.frame marker enrichment results. Conatins following columns: cluster (cluster number) / cellType tissue (based input selection) / database (baDatabase=TRUE) / p (p-value enrichment) / oddsRatio (odds ratio enrichment) / n_olaps (number overlaps variable markers given marker set) / overlaps (specific list markers found variable markers given marker set) / padj ( Benjamini Hochberg adjusted p-value) / neg_log10_padj (-log10(padj))

title:
The function markerEnrich calculates enrichment of cluster-specific
variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone tissue-specific marker
database. — markerEnrich
code: varMarkerFile = system.file("extdata", "cluster_variable_features.csv",                             package = "BoneCellType") varMarkers = read.csv(varMarkerFile) enrichRes = markerEnrich(varMarkers)

title:

cluster-specific variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone

code: markerGSEA(   varMarkers,   markers = NULL,   systemLevel = "cellType",   byDatabase = TRUE,   minSize = 5,   maxSize = 50000 )

title:
The function markerGSEA calculates gene (marker) set enrichment of
cluster-specific variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone
tissue-specific marker database. — markerGSEA
text: varMarkers data.frame containing variable markers cluster reported FindAllMarkers function Seurat package. markers Optional user provided named list markers. systemLevel Optional string specifying systematic level perform enrichment, options: "cellType" "tissue". Default: "cellType". Use providing markers variable. byDatabase Optional logical variable specifying enrichment performed separately database (.e. source  markers obtained): option TRUE (default). database column markerDatabase ignored enrichment done available markers given cellType tissue: option FALSE. Use providing markers variable. minSize Optional number specifying minimal number markers within marker set considered (defaults 5). maxSize Optional umber specifying maximal number markers within marker set considered (defaults 50000).

title:
The function markerGSEA calculates gene (marker) set enrichment of
cluster-specific variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone
tissue-specific marker database. — markerGSEA
text: data.frame following variables: pathway (name list variable markers used GSEA) / pval (p-value) / padj (adjusted p-value) / log2err (log2(error)) / ES (enrichment score) / NES (normalized enrichment score - useful multiple comparisons) / size (number overlaps) / leadingEdge (overlapping markers) / cluster (cluster number)

title:
The function markerGSEA calculates gene (marker) set enrichment of
cluster-specific variable markers within  bone cell type- or bone
tissue-specific marker database. — markerGSEA
code: varMarkerFile = system.file("extdata", "cluster_variable_features.csv",                             package = "BoneCellType") varMarkers = read.csv(varMarkerFile) GSEAres = markerGSEA(varMarkers)  # use own markers markerList = cellType_list GSEAresCustom = markerGSEA(varMarkers, markers=cellType_list)
